content.description: Small edges  and pockets lead to better holds toward the top. Climbing is a little trickier than it at first seems. A few jugs on the right of the bolts lead some people toward the right.
content.protection: 3 bolts to a 2 bolt anchor
content.location: Immediately left of Hair Today, Gone Tomorrow.

content.description:
Interesting face moves on mostly positive holds (after a thin thoughtful start).

Go straight up the middle of the face.

As of 2016 this rock has not been climbed or tested much, so not unlikely if some of it breaks loose. Therefore the climber should wear a helmet, and the belayer and any other persons should stay way off to one side or the other - (not underneath the climber) - (also not anywhere out in front of the route, because falling rocks can bounce and ricochet way out away from the wall).
content.protection:
for Top-Roping, must construct Trad anchor above route. Or use the two-bolt top anchor for The Wave with Trad directional placements.

Protection for Trad leading is unknown and likely inadequate.
content.location:
Just left of The Wave (with three bolts above), is a detached block/pillar about 12 feet high and 8 feet wide. This route starts on the face about seven feet left (west) from the left edge of that block/pillar.

About 50-70 feet east from the access / descent scramble down from the north-side parking.

content.description: Climb the Arete
content.protection: 3 draws plus 2 for the Anchors. No chains so walk off the top.
content.location: The pillar is about 50 ft past damned if you don't.

content.description:
Climb crack and face left of "The Offering".

(I'm sure that we weren't the first to climb this. If you know who was the first Ascensionist and it's proper name, please say so and I'll change that info. Thanks.)
content.protection:
Camalots up to #3

Build gear anchor and belay second up to clean.
content.location: 5' left of "The Offering"

content.description:
Bouldery start with a giant jug beginning. Orient yourself to use smaller ledges and good feet to move through the slab.

I didn't see this route anywhere on MP. If you know the name, grade, and first ascensionist, please comment below.
content.protection: Bolts up top. Can only be top-roped.
content.location: 20 feet left of Hairy Virgin.

content.description: Route climbs a dihedral for the first 15 or so feet and then continues on the face for another 15 feet to the chains. The crux is just above the end of the dihedral- a high step onto the last ledge with hands on sloping hand holds. Overall a pretty fun route. If leading, the last decent piece of pro until just before the top out is at the top of the dihedral. A fall from near the top will land you on top of a ledge or on the deck.
content.protection: Cams, stoppers down low. Bolts with chains at top
content.location: On the opposite side of the arete from what is listed on this site as "Rock!! n Roll." Roughly 50 feet West (left if you're in the canyon facing the wall) from Brazilian Ninjas. There's a relatively easy scramble down next to the route.

content.description: This route starts under a 15' long roof. Use the crack around the left corner for your hands. At the third bolt drop down under the roof. The holds here have been cemented to keep them from breaking off. The crux is from here to the next bolt. follow the arete up to a 2 chain anchor.
content.protection:
Five draws plus anchor

Fixed Bolts. 2 Chain anchor
content.location: About 100 yard from west end of gap on south facing wall. This route in immediately right of Hair Today Gone Tomorrow. It is the most obvious roof with three bolts under the roof.

content.description: Mount boulder under small roof then pull bouldery start to face climbing.
content.protection: 4 bolts to chains
content.location: Just to the right of Ski-Wampus

content.description:
A clean cut, blank corner marks the beginning of this climb, false step or slip and kiss your shin good-bye. Begin from the ground and hold on tight or start from a block and step on a little higher. Either way you're looking at a hard to start route with

OCD

tendencies.

Once you cast off, hang on tight for some great arete climbing with big throws and long moves. Ride the arete, climbing crisp edges mixed with small crimps. Finish a bit mentally and physically drained at a two-bolt anchor.
content.protection: Draws for four bolts and an anchor.
content.location:
Skin Graft

is the line directly on the arete just right of

Perky's Playground

.

content.description: You've gotta embrace the rock, sniff the rock, lick the rock, wash the rock, date the rock, be the rock! And lastly stand on a stack of rocks to get to your first set of crimpers. The first bolt is an easy clip but offers little protection. The route moves up about 4 feet left of the arete. Clipping the last bolt before the chains looks trickier than it actually is. There's a good undercling providing an easy reach to the last bolt.
content.protection: 4 Bolts. Equalized chains at the top.
content.location: There's a grip of routes towards the top of the gap that are not documented. Head up the gap and search out the last obvious routes, about 100 yards-ish from the last largish parking area. The GPS Coords are 37.087562, -113.640104. The climb is on the West side of the rock (you'll be facing East when climbing). The image should make it pretty easy to spot.

content.description: A steep, difficult, under-cut start climbs to jugs and crisp edges. Nice clipping stances and a sweet bulge finish keep this route good from beginning to end. A great little romp!
content.protection: Four bolts to an anchor.
content.location:
This route is the middle climb of three at the early entrance of the

Green Valley Gap

It is on the south facing side and is identified by a roomy cave marking it's start.

content.description:
About 5-10 minutes in the canyon, one will pass by this striking overhanging hand/fist crack in a boulder.  Short but oh so painful.  Give it a go.

I did not get it so my v5, is a guess.
content.protection: good sand landing.

content.description: Steep rock with nice pockets. Crux  involves a dead point to good pocket just above the second bolt.
content.protection: 4 draws
content.location:
North-facing side. If you walk up from the bottom of the

Gap

(about 5 minutes), it is the third route on your left.

content.description:
A name such as this implies a few things.....for me, it says

Saint George

isn't as stale as it appears?

Bolted with the drill in reverse,

Sand Stoner Reverse

has the potential for some nice whippers.

Smooth and potent

, this overhung scoop has some of the best climbing at the gap. Requiring thought, this route isn't as

dumb

as it sounds. A combination of finding proper body position and a need to milk the rests will keep the aspiring climber from getting too

high

too fast. Big powerful moves connect good holds to great holds, plan out your sequence so you don't get

burnt

out.

Smoking

hot! this route is better than it looks.
content.protection: Five bolts to an anchor.
content.location:
Sand Stoner Reverse

is in the

bowl

at the entrance of the gap. It is the first route on the left, north facing side across from

Puppet Strings

.

content.description:
Lots of thoughtful interesting moves in the first twenty feet, then fun easy moves above.

Up directly through the nose above the "practice" anchor, staying left of the "Australian Monk" cracks. Reach a platform, then finish over the roosterhead.

warning

: As of 2018 this rock has not been climbed or tested much, so not unlikely if some of it breaks loose. Therefore the climber should wear a helmet, and the belayer and any other persons should stay way off to one side or the other - (not underneath the climber) - (also not anywhere out in front of the route, because falling rocks can bounce and ricochet way out away from the wall).
content.protection:
Top-Roping from the bolt anchor for the climb to the right of this, supplemented with Trad directional (perhaps sling around horn?)

Protection for trad Leading is unknown and likely inadequate.
content.location:
A foot or two left (west) of the low "practice" anchor (one piton + one old bolt + one newer bolt) on left side of slab with the easier routes ("Chinese Guancho" / "Texas Jug" and "Brazilian Ninja") which is just west from the access scramble down from the north-side parking.

- - >

See sector topo Photo

. . . .

or Left side topo Photo

content.description:
The route starts under a small roof.  Pulling the roof is the crux and then it's smooth sailing after that.

(We might not have been the first to climb this. If you know who was the first Ascensionist and it's proper name, please say so and I'll change that info. Thanks.)
content.protection:
Camalots to #3

Build gear anchor and belay up the second to clean gear.
content.location:
Located between "Brazilian Ninjas" and "Hairy Virgin".

Starts under a small roof where a left leaning crack intersects the vertical crack.

Walk off.

content.description: This route looks really fun (and easy) from the ground, but ends up packing quite the punch once you get on it.  Cruiser climbing leads to the second bolt where the business starts.  Make a hard deadpoint to a sloping crimp with your right hand, then get your feet high and dyno to the jugs above.  The guidebook says 5.12b/c and that the crux involves pinching a tiny cobble. Well, I didn't find any tiny cobble, and the rating felt upper end 5.12c to me, so maybe something broke since the FA.
content.protection: 4 bolts to 2 welded coldshuts
content.location: This is the route between Sandstoner Reverse and Short and Dorkey.  The route is obvious if you are standing at the base of Sandstoner.

content.description: Thin holds on a short, slightly overhanging black streak.
content.protection: 3 bolts. 2 bolt anchor.
content.location: Streaked face just right of Moral Dilemma.

content.description:
This climb is near the east end of the Gap on the south facing side.  It is the left of three routes on the hunk of rock where

Shotgun Baptism

(10c) and

12 Gauge Conversion

(9/TR) are located.  Cimbing is easy up to the third bolt where a bulge is encountered.  Pull through the bulge clip one more bolt on your way to the anchors.
content.protection: 4 bolts, bolted anchor

content.description:
Climb the crack left of "The Wave" up to "The Waves'" Anchor bolts.  Good Placements and fun route.

(We might not have been the first to climb this. If you know who was the first Ascensionist and it's proper name, please say so and I'll change that info. Thanks.)
content.protection: Camalots up to #3.
content.location:
2' left of "The Wave" route.

Walk off to retrieve anchor from the anchor bolts.

content.description:
Crux is the first 10' of the route.  Climb up into a cave-like chimney and pull out of it to easier ground.

(We might not have been the first to climb this. If you know who was the first Ascensionist and it's proper name, please say so and I'll change that info. Thanks.)
content.protection:
Up to Camalot #3

Gear anchor.
content.location:
30' left of "Hairy Virgin" and "The Offering"

Crack to the right of a large white slab.

Build gear anchor and belay up second to retrieve gear and walk off.

content.description: Fun chimney and an easy first lead for beginners.
content.protection: Bolts to chains.
content.location: Right next to Hair Today Gone tomorrow.

content.description: Layback start in the crack to the right of the start of pinball. It is easiest to lead pinball and set up a TR for this climb. Once you get to the top of the crack you finish with pinball and chimney up to the anchor.
content.protection: 3 bolts for Pinball and TR anchor material
content.location: In between Pinball and Hair Today Gone Tommorow

content.description: About 10-15 minutes into the canyon on the North wall, you will see 2 sets of two bolted lines the one on the left is facing east, and the one on the right is facing west, with a third line right on the arete.  This is in the right group and it is the line just left of the arete or the middle line.  A steep varnished face, with really fun moves that almost offset the shortness.
content.protection: 4 draws and 2  (non-rap) hangers at top.  No chains or slings.

content.description:
Thoughtful interesting stemming and other moves in the narrow gully (after working out the "trick" starting move), then easier fun moves above.

Start in the left half of the narrow gully, up the gully, then on to the top (going between the razor on the left and the roosterhead on the right).

warning

: As of 2018 this rock has not been climbed or tested much, so not unlikely if some of it breaks loose. Therefore the climber should wear a helmet, and the belayer and any other persons should stay way off to one side or the other - (not underneath the climber) - (also not anywhere out in front of the route, because falling rocks can bounce and ricochet way out away from the wall).
content.protection:
Top-Roping from the bolt anchor for the climb to the right of this, supplemented with Trad directional (perhaps sling around horn?)

Protection for trad Leading is unknown.
content.location:
The wide crack / narrow gully about ten feet left (west) from the "practice" anchor (one piton + one old bolt + one newer bolt) on left side of slab with the easier routes ("Chinese Guancho" / "Texas Jug" and "Brazilian Ninja") which is just west from the access scramble down from the north-side parking.

- - >

See sector topo Photo

. . . .

or Left side topo Photo

content.description: Just to the left of "Cool Katz."  Mantle start with big moves to nice ledges.  Swing out left to big side pull, bringing you face to face with a serious crux.  Mantle up and finish out with Elvis leg on thin flakes.
content.protection: 5 bolts to equalized chained anchor.  Also can be T.R. easily.
content.location: Just to the left of "Cool Katz"

content.description: Located in between Luck of the Irish and Moral Dilema.  Bouldery start leads to easier 5.9 climbing up top. I think the crux is moving past the first bolt.
content.protection: quickdraws

content.description: Harsh crimping on hard varnish past three bolts.
content.protection: 3 bolts and anchor

content.description: Awesome route with bouldery balance lower crux that leads to fun climbing to the top.
content.protection: 3 bolts to 2 bolt anchor.
content.location: area between moral dilemma and stick to your guns.  left route from luck of the irish.

content.description: Big fun moves on a pocketed sandstone arete. This route is in the shade by 1200. Possible to do in summer. Longer draws will reduce rope drag.
content.protection:
Five Quick Draws + Anchor

Five Bolts + 2 bolt anchor. No chains or rap rings.
content.location: By the 3rd main pull off. on the east side of the arete.

content.description: Thin crimps with big pockets above. Short but fun. Good warm up.
content.protection: 3 bolts to a 2 bolt anchor which needs to be extended with slings.  Walk off
content.location: Around the corner from Moral Dilemma.

content.description:
Huge Right facing Dihedral in between "Skin Graft" and "Fat Black Chuck".  Hand jam the crack and pull on the occasional face hold.  Great hold in the crack make this an interesting and fun lead. This is a short route, but it is totally worth the time.

(We might not have been the first to climb this. If you know who was the first Ascensionist and it's proper name, please say so and I'll change that info. Thanks.)
content.protection:
Camalots from #.75 to #3

Build gear and boulder anchor to belay second up to clean.
content.location:
Located about 30-40 yards right of "Skin Graft"

Crack is in Huge Dihedral behind a bush.

content.description: Start next to arete and crimp upwards and right. Shares anchor with Nephites.
content.protection: 3 bolts and anchor

climbs.name: Kool Kats Chimney
climbs.fa: probably been done many times by bored parties

content.description: Climb the chimney to left of Kool Kats and only use the chimney to the top where you reach the anchors of Kool Kats. used my shoulder and neck and everything I had to get to the top. super stretched out.
content.protection: bolts at top with chain
content.location: to the left of Kool Kats.

content.description: Start in the crack to the right then move left onto the face.  Expect some gritty edges until it gets more traffic.
content.protection: 5 bolts to chains
content.location: Immediately right of Stick to Your Guns

content.description: Short yet fun offwidth crack with a lightning bolt crux
content.protection: One #3 and two #4's to anchors
content.location: Just to the left of Lincoln's Lament

content.description: Great route for the grade. Starts on a small roof; pulling over the edge leads to vertical climbing to anchors.  Crux is beneath the first bolt so bring a stick clip.  A spotter through the first section is helpful to keep a climber from hitting their back on the boulder directly behind the first moves in the event of a fall.
content.protection: Four bolts to two-bolt anchor.
content.location:
South-facing side. Second-to-last route in the canyon. Fifteen yards west of

Hair Today Gone Tomorrow

.

climbs.name: I'm hungry and I have to poop!

content.description: Stick clip first bolt, Shares start with "stick to your Guns".  Traverse out and up the face on thin crimps to nice ledge, set up for mono and finish with compression and big moves to the chains
content.protection: 3 bolts, to equalized anchor.
content.location: Located between "hair today gone tomorrow, and "stick to your guns".  shares start with "stick to your guns."  Do not clip first bolt of Stick to your guns, your belayer will not like this if you fall

content.description: Boulder out of a scoop onto the arete (don't bother clipping the first bolt, it's too low to catch you anyhow).  As the angle eases on the arete, the holds get sparse and small, making for continuous (although easier) climbing.  Clip the last bolt before pulling the roof and then make an easy mantle to the top.  This was a lot of fun for such a short route.  My best guess is 5.9+ on difficulty, hopefully I don't sandbag anyone.
content.protection: 4 bolts to a one bolt anchor (there is another hanger about 6 feet away that can be slung for a backup.
content.location: An arete with a scoop out of the bottom and a roof at the top.  There is a decent route with a rippled slab to the west.  Walk off recommended.

content.description: New route as of April 2020.  Tricky start onto easy face with a reachy move to the chains.
content.protection: 4 bolts to chain anchors

content.description: Who thinks of these names?  I hope that this isn't what people think of while climbing.  This is a fun little route for groups of beginners or small children.  Pretty fun for a short 5.7 (beta I got), seemed easier than that to me.
content.protection: There are lots of hangers up top, but it seems that one from every pair has been smashed.  There is on hanger in the middle that can be used as a backup with some long slings.
content.location: On the east face of an arete with a scoop out of the bottom and a roof at the top.  There is a decent path to the west with a rippled slab.

content.description: This route starts in the 5.10 range with deep pocket. At the second bolt the You move to thin edges. The roof starts at the third bolt. Use the right corner to lay back and hit the fourth bolt. The back under the roof for a daring mantle to a comfortable ledge and a two bolt anchor.
content.protection:
Four quick draw plus anchor

Four bolts to chain anchor
content.location: Park at the last parking lot. This is route "S" in the guilde book. About 100 Yard from the west end of the Gap on the south facing wall. The roof  sweeps out about 25 feet up. Just left of the long 10' roof of a project route.

content.description:
Route name is a placeholder for this shiny new line just left of Fat Black Chuck -- name correction welcome!

Easy clips protect the gentle start and keep you safe as you make a bold move to the third bolt's clipping crimps.  Several options let you gamble on what will stick.  From here it's thin holds and feet on up to the top.  Great fun!
content.protection: 4 bolts to a 2-bolt anchor. Traverse up and right to use the rap rings under the roof.
content.location: This is the left of three routes at the second most significant buttress. It sits on the south facing wall off the trail near the entrance of the Gap.

content.description:
Climb using a few good pockets up the front face of a pillar to a crux at the mid-way point. Finish steep at the anchor.

Well protected climbing ends on steep terrain with hidden holds. Sequential and Exciting!
content.protection: Four bolts. A two-bolt anchor with rap rings now hangs below the roof.
content.location: This is the middle of three routes at the second most significant buttress. It sits on the south facing wall off the trail near the entrance of the Gap. Its anchors sit just below a large protruding roof.

content.description: This route is labeled "P" in Todd Goss's "Rock Climbs of Southwest Utah" guidebook from 2006.  It is the short varnished slab just East of Moral Dilemma and The Quickening.  It is short and definitely not the most inspiring line in the area, but offers some decent edgy features to warm up on.
content.protection: Two-bolt TR anchor

content.description:
A Dangerous and Bold undertaking.

This poorly bolted, mis-leading, death route will cause jaw dropping or denture dropping results. I would recommend being very solid at the grade before leading this route. Hard clips with deck potential mark the first 15 feet. A tense and very steep finish keep you on your toes. Relentless...
content.protection: Four randomly placed bolts to a two-bolt anchor.
content.location:
At the second most significant buttress from the entrance of the Gap,

Dueling Grandmas

sits recessed and on the right side of the small wall. Its most recognized by its up and left sweeping wave 10 feet off the ground.

37.0889598°, -113.6357960°

content.description: About 10-15 minutes into the canyon on the North wall, you will see 2 sets of two bolted lines the one on the left is facing east, and the one on the right is facing west, with a third line right on the arete. This route (along with it's sister, Damned If You Do) are around the corner from the two on the left. They climb the varnished edgy steep face, to the top.  This is the right line.
content.protection: No gear. This route has a dedicated two-bolt anchor, plus the two-bolt anchor for "Damned If You Do" is three feet away. Six feet further up from both of these anchors is yet another two-bolt anchor that is good for re-direct if you are belaying from above.

content.description: About 10-15 minutes into the canyon on the North wall, you will see 2 sets of two bolted lines the one on the left is facing east, and the one on the right is facing west, with a third line right on the arete.  This route (along with it's sister, Damned If You Don't) are around the corner from the two on the left.  They climb the varnished edgy steep face, to the top.  This is the left line.
content.protection: No gear. This route has a dedicated two-bolt anchor, plus the two-bolt anchor for "Damned If You Don't" is three feet away. Six feet further up from both of these anchors is yet another two-bolt anchor that is good for re-direct if you are belaying from above.

content.description:
Terribly solid for the grade,

Cool Katz

is possibly the best entry level route at

The Green Valley Gap

. Despite its crimperific start,

Cool Katz

is a straight shooting line that starts hard and eases off towards the end.

Nice climbing on a blunt arete passes good holds and sharp crimps. Break through the start and enjoy easier moves to the anchor.
content.protection: Four bolts to a two bolt anchor.
content.location:
Cool Katz

sits on the far northwest end of

The Green Valley Gap

. Its directly left of

The Inquisition

.

LAT LONG GRID

37.0881743°, -113.6403133°  Taken from base of route 04062020

content.description:
8' left of "Brazilian Ninjas".  Climb past the bottom anchor bolt set up to seam/small dihedral.  It's a little run out at the end on easy ground to chains.

(I'm sure that we weren't the first to climb this.  If you know who was the first Ascensionist and it's proper name, please say so and I'll change that info.  Thanks.)
content.protection: Small nuts to bomber chain anchor.
content.location: 8' left of "Brazilian Ninjas" just right of the Piton, bolt, and crappy bolt practice anchor.

climbs.name: Cass's Pain
climbs.fa: I'm sure I'm not the first.

content.description: Decent climb up a wavering crack. I can't find it in the Goss book and it's not Kool Katz Chimney so I guess I'll add it, and take it down if necessary.  The crux for this route is getting your feet on the wall and the last move or two.
content.protection: Could use Hot Grandma's chains to the right, otherwise, no chains.
content.location: Follows the crack right of "Pain in the Cass"

content.description:
The first 15ft starts out in a skinny offwidth and quickly changes to a fist crack that is slightly overhung. After that Veer left and up to the top. Watch out for loose rocks!!

Build an anchor and belay up your partner, walk off

(We might not have been the first to climb this. If you know who was the first Ascensionist and it's proper name, please say so!)
content.protection: BD#1-3 one #4. Bring some smaller gear for the anchor.
content.location: In between Skin Graft and Jezabel about 50ft to the right of Skin Graft. The route begins on the left side of an obvious small cave under a big bulge of rock.

content.description:
Sustained thoughtful moves for the first twenty feet (with sidepulls and footholds on both sides of the crest). Then easier fun moves up the "razor" to the top.

Start up the gully to right bottom of arete. About five feet up, step horizontal left over onto crest of the arete (onto unseen big foothold using unseen big handhold).

. . . Variation 1 (like 5.9): Start on the face about four feet left from the arete for the first couple of moves, then move right to join the arete.

. . . Variation 2 (harder): Start directly on the arete.

Straight up the crest of arete, then finish up the razor.

warning

: As of 2018 this rock has not been climbed or tested much, so not unlikely if some of it breaks loose. Therefore the climber should wear a helmet, and the belayer and any other persons should stay way off to one side or the other - (not underneath the climber) - (also not anywhere out in front of the route, because falling rocks can bounce and ricochet way out away from the wall).
content.protection:
If Top-Roping from the bolt anchor for the climb to the right of this, need to supplement with Trad directional (perhaps sling around horn?) to protect against a falling climber swinging sideway and hitting a protruding rock.

Or perhaps better to construct a natural anchor which is more above this arete.

Protection for trad Leading is unknown and likely inadequate.
content.location:
About fifteen feet left (west) from the "practice" anchor (one piton + one old bolt + one newer bolt) on left side of slab with the easier routes ("Chinese Guancho" / "Texas Jug" and "Brazilian Ninja") which is just west from the access scramble down from the north-side parking.

The light-brown Butterflies arete forms the left side of the narrow gully / wide crack of the "Parking Slot" route.

- - >

See sector topo Photo

. . . .

also left side topo Photo

content.description:
About 5-10 minutes further up the canyon from the Damned sisters, is this child's route. It can be TR'd or gear protected.

Coordinates MGRS 12S TG 65553 07936 Taken from the base of the route 03272020
content.protection: #.75, #1 and a few medium stoppers.

content.description: A tricky and hard to read line with a tough clip or two. Climb a bulge that leads to crimps and a blind throw. Gain a rest and work left over steepening terrain towards a small roof. The final moves involve questionable climbing through friable sandstone. Hand and foot holds with limited life greet you at the end of this this route right before you want to start cursing.
content.protection: Three or Four Bolts to a two-bolt anchor. Slings or a cordelette come in handy at the top as the anchor is set further back in more solid stone.
content.location:
Bitter Recriminations

is the first route you come to when entering the Gap. It sits alone on the south side slightly raised off the floor. Do a small scramble and belay at the base.

content.description:
There is no

benefit of the doubt

to be given here, either you can start this route or you can't.

A powerful, yet cautious, bouldery beginning marks the crux of this route. Blowing the second, difficult clip could get ugly. Proper body position and strong tendons get you going, find the few remaining hidden crimps and continue up through smoother, more flowing terrain.

Whats bad? A crumbly and potentially dangerous start.

Whats good? Solid varnished edges, good pockets, and great movement.
content.protection: Four bolts to a difficult to mash, bend, break, or steal, two-bolt anchor.
content.location:
Benefit of the Doubt

is one of the last bolted routes on the south facing wall. It is the next route left of

Where Ego's Dare

content.description: Crimpy, fun but short.
content.protection: 4 Draws plus 2 for the Anchors. Walk off. no chains to rappel off of.
content.location: The route is just left(6ft) of Perky's Playground on the same face.

content.description: Good route for beginners.  Decent moves up to a 2 bolt anchor.
content.protection: 3 bolts to 2 bolt anchor.  Second bolt is a spinner and will be fixed soon.
content.location: first route right of Stick to your guns, 2 routes left of Luck of the Irish.

content.description:
Climb the duel cracks in the slabby chimney up to the chain anchors.

It's still kinda loose so watch out.

(I'm sure that we weren't the first to climb this. If you know who was the first Ascensionist and it's proper name, please say so and I'll change that info. Thanks.)
content.protection: Nuts to #2 camalot.
content.location:
12' left of "Brazilian Ninjas".  Left of bolt and piton practice anchor.

Rap off chains.

content.description: Campus start up through big holds, enter the crux with a diaper on, because your going to shit.  Finish out on good holds.
content.protection: 4 bolts to equalized chained anchors. Shared first bolt with Fear no evil, the climb that banks off to the left..
content.location: 50 yards to the left of "Pain in the Cass"  Park at the very last parking spot. Head west approximately 25 yards to the obvious down climb into the canyon.  Once at the bottom turn right and walk approximately 50 feet, climbs will be on your right. The two prominent climbs on overhang.

content.description: This route is located near the east end of the south facing side of the gap, on a nice hunk of rock.  There are two other routes on this hunk to the left.  When facing the cliff from right to left the routes are: 12 Gauge Conversion(9/TR), Shotgun Baptism(10c), and Puppet Strings(10a).
content.protection: This climb has no lead bolts but is easily TRed from fixed anchors on top.
